sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Web Port to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: __PoolID
sci:arg.sci:help:
__PoolID is a case insensitive string that can optionally be set to optimize the speed of execution for quick running protocols. Multiple protocols with the same value for __PoolID can share expensive resources such as database connections, Java VMs, memory, etc. reducing the execution time by 1 to 2 seconds per run. This can give a large speed improvement to protocols that run in a few seconds such as web applications and interactive reports. Longer running protocols will not see much benefit. Generally, it is a good idea to use the same __PoolID for all protocols within a single application such as an interactive report since many of the components, databases, and data structures will be similar.

__PoolID can also be specified by the client when the protocol is launched. If __PoolID is specified both as a parameter by the client and as a parameter stored within the protocol, the client's value overrides the stored value.

To disable pooling entirely for this particular protocol, set __PoolID to <Disable>

sci:arg.name: Http Cookie Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Http Cookie Handling provides a mechanism to control the handling of Http cookies within components that access remote resources via Http and Https. These include the HTTP Connector, Data readers such as Text Reader, XML Reader (Generic), etc., and custom Java, Perl, and .Net components that use the available APIs for accessing remote servers. By default, New Protocols will have this setting enabled and set to "Protocol Scope". This means that Http cookies obtained from a remote server within any component in the protocol or any of its subprotocols will be parsed and appropriately sent back on subsequent requests from the same component or any other component. The handling of the cookies is based on the IETF standard as specified in http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265. Setting the parameter to Disabled will prevent components from parsing and returning cookies to the remote servers.

Persistence of cookies is not supported, so scoping of Http cookies is entirely within the context of a single protocol execution.

Older protocols that do not have the Http Cookie Handling parameter will behave as though it had been set to "Disabled". To enable cookie handling in these protocols, copy this parameter from a New Protocol to the older protocol and set the parameter as desired.

sci:arg.name: Reporting
sci:arg.sci:help: This group contains parameters specific to protocols containing Reporting components.

sci:arg.name: Reporting Stylesheet
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the name of a Stylesheet to be used by this protocol if any of the Reporting components have a Style selected in the Format and Position parameters.

sci:arg.name: Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: The Run On Grid parameter tells the server to run the protocol on the grid engine if SES is configured to run with grid integration.

sci:arg.name: Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: The Queue Name allows you to specify the name of the queue on the grid engine to submit the job to. Leave blank to specify the default queue.

sci:arg.name: Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Grid Options allows you to specify options to the grid engine submit command. Leave blank to specify the default options.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: WebExports
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties which will be automatically exported if this protocol is published as a web service.

Each global property in the list is created with an empty value at the start of the protocol run.

sci:arg.name: Keep Alive
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies if the process where this protocol is run should stay around for later use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: An example of interactive data visualization.

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Include Live Molecule
sci:arg.sci:help:
If the Include Live Molecule parameter is set to True and this component is piped into an HTML report, the image will be backed by live molecular data, so that double-clicking will open the chemistry in 3rd party sketcher software like Accelrys Draw (or ISIS/Draw) or ChemDraw. With Include Live Molecule set to True, this component is equivalent to the read-only version of the Chemistry Sketcher component. Its main advantage is scalability: multiple instances of this component may be included in a single HTML report without significantly affecting browser performance. Unlike the Chemistry Sketcher component, this component should not be used in forms, as the chemistry is not editable.

You can right-click on the output image to copy the currently displayed chemistry to the clipboard or to change the preferred sketcher software to be opened when the image is double-clicked.

This component uses a signed Java applet to launch 3rd party sketcher software. You will need to have the Java plug-in installed in your browser and will need to accept the Accelrys security certificate before using the applet. Whichever chemistry sketcher you are using (Accelrys Draw or ChemDraw) must be installed on the client machine in order to edit the molecule.

When true, the image type will always be PNG, and the Image Map Name and most of the Links and Actions will be disabled.

Notes:

  • Users with more than one of the Accelrys Draw or ISIS/Draw sketchers installed will see Accelrys Draw launched in preference to ISIS/Draw. Those sketchers should be run from the desktop at least once before the applet can properly launch them to display a molecule.
  • To create live, embedded chemistry in Office documents, use Office Chemistry Sketcher.

sci:arg.name: Sketch Tool
sci:arg.sci:help:
The default sketcher application to launch when the user double clicks on the molecule.

The sketcher type can be changed in the final report by right-clicking on the molecule image. Once a user has chosen a preferred sketcher via the right-click menu, their preference is stored in a cookie, and it supersedes what may be specified on this component.

The sketcher type is global across all instances of this component in a report, and the default value will be taken from the first instance in the protocol.

Users with more than one of the Accelrys Draw or ISIS/Draw sketchers installed will see Accelrys Draw launched in preference to ISIS/Draw. Those sketchers should be run from the desktop at least once before the applet can properly launch them to display a molecule.

sci:arg.name: Image Type
sci:arg.sci:help:
Format to use to represent the molecular image.
  • PNG: Portable Network Graphics.
  • JPEG: Joint Photographic Experts Group.
  • SVG: Scalable Vector Graphics.
  • EMF: Windows Enhanced Meta File.
  • BMP: Windows Bitmap.
  • TIFF: Tagged Image File Format.

Note that SVG may give the best results if outputting to a PDF document.

sci:arg.name: ImageSize
sci:arg.sci:help: Size of the square image, in pixels
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Formatting to be applied to the reporting element produced by this component. Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, Color, and Background Color.

Notes:
  • Color: Sets font color
  • Background Image: Allows you to select a background image for the reporting element. This image must be accessible to the Pipeline Pilot server to be used (for example, you can copy images to the apps\scitegic\core\dataroot\data\Images folder in your Pipeline Pilot installation to make them available). Supported image types include .gif, .jpg, .png, and .bmp.

sci:arg.name: Position
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how the element is positioned. Editing this parameter opens the Position dialog, which enables you to change margins, paddings, width, and height.

sci:arg.name: Image Map Name
sci:arg.sci:help: When used in conjunction with an Image Map component, the name of the image map to be used by the generated image. This parameter should match the Name parameter of the corresponding Image Map component.

sci:arg.name: Caption Property
sci:arg.sci:help:
The property used to display a caption for the picture. If this parameter is not defined, a caption is not displayed.

Note:

  • The caption does not utilize any Format settings. If you want to control formatting of the caption, use a Text component for the caption, in combination with this component, in a Run-to-Completion subprotocol.

sci:arg.name: Molecule Scaling
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to scale the molecule to the desired image size.
  • Fixed Image Size: the size of the images is the same for all the input molecules. The size of the image (in pixels) is controlled by ImageSize, which specifies the width and height. The aspect ratio is set to 1 by default, but can be modified by WidthToHeightRatio which sets the width as the height multiplied by the ratio. MaximumBondLengthSize can be used to define a maximum limit for the length of the lines used to draw the bonds (to prevent very small molecules such as ethane to be drawn disproportionally big).
  • Fixed Bond Length: all the molecules are drawn with the same bond length, specified by BondLengthSize. The image size depends on the size of the molecule. Small molecules create small images and big molecules create big images.
  • Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length: the size of the images , specified by ImageSize, is the same for all the input molecules but, if possible, the molecules are drawn using the bond length specified by BondLengthSize. If the molecule can be drawn within the specified image size using the desired bond length, it is drawn like that, padding with white space as necessary. if the molecule is too big to be drawn with the desired bond length, it is scaled down to fit in the dimensions specified by image size.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length

sci:arg.name: MaximumBondLengthSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Maximum size allowed for the lines used to draw the bonds in the molecule, in pixels. This parameter is used in conjunction with ImageSize to set a limit to how long the bonds in the molecule can be. This is useful to prevent small molecules, such as ethane, to be drawn disproportionally big.
Leave empty if you don't want to set a limit to the bond length.

sci:arg.name: MaximumImageSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Maximum size allowed for the image, in pixels. This parameter is used in conjunction with BondLengthSize to set a limit to how big the image can be.
Leave empty if you don't want to set a limit to the image size.

sci:arg.name: BondLengthSize
sci:arg.sci:help:
Size of the average bond length, in pixels.

This parameter is used when Molecule Scaling is set to "Fixed Bond Length" or "Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length".

The size of the image will not be constant. Bigger molecules generate larger images; smaller molecules generate smaller images.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Bond Length' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: WidthToHeightRatio
sci:arg.sci:help: The ratio of the width to the height. When not equal to 1.0, the image height is given by ImageSize and the image width is scaled to fit the given WidthToHeightRatio.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size' or parameter('Molecule Scaling') eq 'Fixed Image Size with Fixed Bond Length'

sci:arg.name: Use Global Depiction Settings
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, the depiction options are set based on the settings specified by Global Depiction Settings and not from the component parameters.

sci:arg.name: Global Depiction Settings
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the XML file in the /apps/chemistry/xml/Objects folder with the global depiction settings.

The default XML file, with the same depiction settings as the default values of the component parameters, is PPDepictionSettings_Defaults.xml.

Use Export Depiction Parameters to modify and save depiction settings to use them as global settings.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use Global Depiction Settings") eq true

sci:arg.name: Depiction Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Options that control the molecular depictions
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter("Use Global Depiction Settings") eq False

sci:arg.name: Atoms
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of atoms and atom labels

sci:arg.name: AtomLabelsScaleFactor
sci:arg.sci:help: Factor to scale the size of the atom labels (atom type, atom number, valence, value, charge). Set this factor to the default value of 1.0 to use the font size determined internally by PipelinePilot. Values greater than 1.0 will increase the font size. Values smaller than 1.0 will decrease the font size.

sci:arg.name: DisplayHighlightedAtomsAs
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select how to highlight selected atoms.
  • ColoredBlocks: Display a colored block superimposed on all the selected atoms.
  • ColoredLabels: Color all the selected atom labels with the same highlight color.

sci:arg.name: DrawImplicitHydrogens
sci:arg.sci:help:
Defines which implicit Hydrogen atoms to draw:
  • AllHydrogens: Displays all implicit Hydrogen atoms (this option overrides the other options).
  • HeteroHydrogens: Displays implicit Hydrogen atoms on heteroatoms.
  • TerminalCarbonHydrogens: Displays implicit Hydrogen atoms on terminal Carbon atoms.

sci:arg.name: AtomLabelPadding
sci:arg.sci:help: Padding size, in percentage of the average bond length, to use around atom type labels in the molecular image. This parameter controls how much white space to leave between atom type labels and the lines representing bonds.

sci:arg.name: Display Charge
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display non-zero atom charges

sci:arg.name: Display Valence
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display non-standard atom valences

sci:arg.name: Display Star Atoms As
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to display unknown star (*) atoms
  • As a star (*).
  • As a zigzag line.

sci:arg.name: Display 'Pol' Atoms As Circles
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to display 'Pol' atom types as a circle. When set to False, these atoms are displayed using a 'Pol' label.

sci:arg.name: Display Hydrogen Isotopes as 2H and 3H
sci:arg.sci:help: When set to True, Hydrogen isotopes are displayed as '2H' and '3H' instead of 'D' and 'T'

sci:arg.name: Bonds
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of bonds and bond labels

sci:arg.name: DrawAromaticRings
sci:arg.sci:help:
How to draw aromatic rings.
  • UsingSingleDoubleBonds: A kekule representation using alternating single and double bonds.
  • AsSolidCircles: A solid circle is drawn inside the aromatic ring.

sci:arg.name: DisplayHighlightedBondsAs
sci:arg.sci:help:
Select how to highlight selected bonds.
  • ColoredLines: Color all the selected bonds with the specified highlight color.
  • ThickLines: Use a thicker line to draw the selected bonds.
  • ThickColoredLines: Use a thicker line and the highlight color to draw the selected bonds.

sci:arg.name: Draw Bond Query Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to draw labels indicating the bond query types (s/d, s/a, d/a, ...)

sci:arg.name: Position of Bond Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the position of bond labels, such as query bond types (any, s/d, s/a, d/a), topologies (Ch, Rn), or bond numbers. The labels are placed either at one side of the bond or on top of the bond.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: At One Side of the Bond

sci:arg.name: Bond Thickness
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify the thickness of the lines used to represent bonds

sci:arg.name: Double Bond Width
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the width of double bonds, as a fraction of the bond length

sci:arg.name: Wedge Bond Width
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the width of stereo bond wedges, as a fraction of the bond length (including Either bonds)

sci:arg.name: Spacing of Down Bond Hashes
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the spacing between the lines of down bond wedges

sci:arg.name: DrawUnknownDoubleBonds
sci:arg.sci:help: How to draw double bonds with unknown stereochemistry (such as in molecules read from SMILES); either AsStandardDoubleBond or AsCrossedLines.
sci:arg.sci:member: Include Double Bonds in Small Rings

sci:arg.name: Include Double Bonds in Small Rings
sci:arg.sci:help: If False (the default), double bonds in small rings (size 7 or less) are never displayed as cross lines even if they are marked as unknown cis/trans stereo.

sci:arg.name: Colors
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the selection of colors to draw the structures

sci:arg.name: UseColor
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to true, the molecular image will be colored according to atom types. If false, the image will be black and white only.

sci:arg.name: Background Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify the background color to use to draw the image.
Transparent should be set to 'False' for this parameter to be active.

sci:arg.name: Foreground Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify the foreground color to use to draw the image.

sci:arg.name: H
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw H atoms.

sci:arg.name: Li
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Li atoms.

sci:arg.name: B
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw B atoms.

sci:arg.name: C
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw C atoms.

sci:arg.name: N
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw N atoms.

sci:arg.name: O
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw O atoms.

sci:arg.name: F
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw F atoms.

sci:arg.name: Na
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Na atoms.

sci:arg.name: Mg
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Mg atoms.

sci:arg.name: Al
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Al atoms.

sci:arg.name: Si
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Si atoms.

sci:arg.name: P
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw P atoms.

sci:arg.name: S
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw S atoms.

sci:arg.name: Cl
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Cl atoms.

sci:arg.name: K
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw K atoms.

sci:arg.name: Ca
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Ca atoms.

sci:arg.name: Se
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Se atoms.

sci:arg.name: Br
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Br atoms.

sci:arg.name: Sn
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Sn atoms.

sci:arg.name: I
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw I atoms.

sci:arg.name: Fe
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Fe atoms.

sci:arg.name: Cu
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Cu atoms.

sci:arg.name: Ag
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Ag atoms.

sci:arg.name: Cd
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Cd atoms.

sci:arg.name: Au
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Au atoms.

sci:arg.name: Hg
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw Hg atoms.

sci:arg.name: Other
sci:arg.sci:help: Color to use to draw all other atoms.

sci:arg.name: Fonts
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the selection of fonts to draw the structures

sci:arg.name: TrueType Font File
sci:arg.sci:help: Path of the TrueType font to use to display the labels in the picture. Leave empty to use the default font.

sci:arg.name: SVG Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font family to use to draw text in SVG images.
Enter any valid SVG font-family specification.
Leave empty to use default font (Arial, Helvetica)

sci:arg.name: FixedFontSizeToDrawLabels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify a fixed font size to be used to draw the text labels in the molecular image. Text labels include atom labels (atom type, charge, isotope, implicit hydrogens, query features and custom labels and numbers), bond labels (query features, custom labels and numbers), molecule caption, chiral flag and custom labels.

If a fixed font size is specified, the labels are always drawn with the same size, irrespective of the molecule size.

Leave blank to scale the font size based on the size of the molecule.

sci:arg.name: MinimumFontSizeToDrawLabels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies the minimum font size required to draw text labels for atoms, bonds and for the entire molecule (caption, chiral flag, etc). The font size used to draw these labels is calculated based on the size of the molecule. If it is smaller than the value of this parameter, labels are not drawn and heteroatoms are represented by circles with the color of the corresponding atom.

Leave blank to force the drawing of the text labels, even at very small font sizes.

sci:arg.name: Caption Font Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font size to use to draw the captions.

Leave blank to calculate the size automatically based on the image size and the length of the caption

sci:arg.name: Chemistry Labels Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the structure labels for atoms, bonds, abbreviations and Sgroup data.

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Captions Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the caption label

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Stereo Configuration Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the stereochemistry labels

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: Sequence Label Font
sci:arg.sci:help:
Font to use to draw the sequence labels

Note:

  • On Windows systems, text labels are drawn differently for each of the fonts in the dropdown list. On Linux systems, the same font family is used for groups of fonts:
    • Arial
    • Bookman Old Style
    • Calibri, Cambria, Century Schoolbook, Garamond, Goudy Old Style, Lucida Console, MS Sans Serif, System, Tahoma, Verdana
    • Courier New
    • Times New Roman

sci:arg.name: General
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control general image settings

sci:arg.name: Transparent
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to true, the image will be transparent. If false, the image will have a white background.

sci:arg.name: Antialiasing
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to use antialiasing when drawing graphic objects in the molecular image

sci:arg.name: Haptic/Markush
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Markush bonds and Pi systems

sci:arg.name: Haptic Bond Display
sci:arg.sci:help:
Type of line to use to display Pi systems
  • Solid line.
  • Dotted line.

sci:arg.name: Markush Attachment Point Shape
sci:arg.sci:help:
Type of symbol to use to display the atoms representing Markush attachment points
  • Circle
  • Square
  • Star (*)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color1
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the first Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color2
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the second Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color3
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the third Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Markush Color4
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use for the atoms that would be attached to the fourth Markush bond (will cycle after the fourth Markush bond)

sci:arg.name: Reactions
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of reactions

sci:arg.name: Display Atom-Atom Mapping
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether or not to display the atom-atom mappings when depicting reactions

sci:arg.name: Display Reacting Center Marks
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies how to display the reacting center marks of reactants and products when depicting reactions
  • Hash Marks (For Change)
  • Color (For Change)
  • Thicker (For Change)
  • All Marks
  • Off

sci:arg.name: Display Stereo Markers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether or not to display the stereo inversion and/or retention marks when depicting reactions

sci:arg.name: Rgroups
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Rgroups
sci:arg.sci:member: Maximum Number of Members to Display

sci:arg.name: Display Attachment Points As
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies how to display the attachment points in Rgroup fragments
  • Template (Z) Atoms
  • Arrow and Star (*)
  • Line and Zigzag line

sci:arg.name: Maximum Number of Members to Display
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies maximum number of Rgroup members to be defined. If the RG structure includes more members, it will simply display numbers of members.

sci:arg.name: Sequences
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of biological sequences

sci:arg.name: Show Sequence View
sci:arg.sci:help: Shows sequence structure in the sequence view

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - First
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the chain in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - Second
sci:arg.sci:help: Alternate color of the chain in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Chain Color - Other
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of other chain types like Signal Peptides in Sequence

sci:arg.name: Mutations Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color to use to draw mutated residues in the biopolymer sequence.
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Modifications Color
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color to use to draw modified residues in the biopolymer sequence.
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Default
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink in sequence

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Disulfide
sci:arg.sci:help:
Color of the disulfide bridges in the sequence
The color can be defined as a string with three comma-separated integers between 0 and 255 representing the RGB numbers (example: 200,0,0) or as one of the predefined color names (Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Cyan, Magenta, Black).

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Lactam
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink that forms lactam bridge in sequence

sci:arg.name: Crosslinks Color - Lactone
sci:arg.sci:help: Color of the crosslink that forms lactone bridge in sequence

sci:arg.name: Sequence Block Size
sci:arg.sci:help: If this value is greater than 0, sequence structure will be displayed as the sequence labels blocked in this size. '0' means no blocking.

sci:arg.name: Sequence Wrap Length
sci:arg.sci:help: If this value is greater than 0, the sequence wraps to the next line after this number of sequence labels. '0' means no wrapping.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Labels
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence labels.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Blocks
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence blocks.

sci:arg.name: Spacing between Sequence Lines
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies spacing between sequence lines.

sci:arg.name: Display Sequence Block Numbers
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true and there is sequence block size set, colume number at the end of each block is displayed at the top of the sequence.

sci:arg.name: Display Sequence Line Numbers
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true, multiple line Sequence is displayed with starting number at the beginning of each row of sequences.

sci:arg.name: Show Expanded Sequence Structure
sci:arg.sci:help: If this setting is true, expanded sequence residue shows its explicit structure instead of label.

sci:arg.name: Sgroups
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of Sgroups

sci:arg.name: DrawFunctionalGroups
sci:arg.sci:help:
Draw specific functional groups as text instead of the actual atoms and bonds.

  • The functional groups to draw are defined using substructure searching with queries contained in the directory specified by FunctionalGroupsQueries. The default location of the functional group queries is /data/Queries/FunctionalGroups.
  • Each functional group query mol file must define the text to be drawn, the text color, and the core atom that connects the functional group to the rest of the molecule. Only functional groups with a single core atom are allowed.

sci:arg.name: FunctionalGroupsQueries
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the functional group queries.

sci:arg.name: Stereochemistry
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of stereochemistry labels
sci:arg.sci:member: Stereo Label for R at Absolute Centers
Stereo Label for R at AND Centers
Stereo Label for R at OR Centers
Stereo Label for S at Absolute Centers
Stereo Label for S at AND Centers
Stereo Label for S at OR Centers

sci:arg.name: Chirality Label Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify the labels to use to identify the stereo configuration of the molecule. The chirality label is drawn at the top of the molecular image.
  • Pipeline Pilot Defaults
    • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group: '' (no label).
    • All marked centers in one absolute group: 'Chiral'.
    • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group: 'Chiral Unknown'.
    • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type: 'Relative'.
  • Accelrys Draw Defaults
    • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group: 'AND Enantiomer'.
    • All marked centers in one absolute group: '' (no label).
    • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group: 'OR Enantiomer'.
    • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type: 'Mixed'.
  • Custom Labels
    Comma-separated strings with the labels to use to identify the chiral state of molecule. Four strings should be defined, with labels corresponding to the chiral states described above for the Pipeline Pilot and Accelrys Draw defaults.

sci:arg.name: Chirality Labels
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma-separated strings with the labels to use to identify the chiral state of molecule. Four strings should be defined, with labels corresponding to the following chiral states:
  • All marked centers in one AND Enantiomer group.
  • All marked centers in one absolute group.
  • All marked centers in one OR Enantiomer group.
  • Marked centers in more than one stereogroup type.

sci:arg.name: Color of Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Color of AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Color of OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color in which the stereo bonds, the stereo group labels or both are displayed at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Display Labels for Stereogenic Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Specify whether or not to display labels for the stereogenic centers (Abs, AND, OR)

sci:arg.name: Display Labels for Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify whether or not to display labels for the absolute stereogenic centers (Abs).

This parameter controls the display of Abs labels only. Use Display Labels for Stereogenic Centers to control the display of all labels (Abs, AND, OR)

sci:arg.name: Color Stereogenic Centers
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specify how to color the stereogenic centers with the colors specified by Color of Absolute Centers, Color of AND Centers, Color of OR Centers
  • Labels Only: color only the atom labels (Abs, AND, OR)
  • Bonds Only: color only the stereo bonds
  • Labels and Bonds: color both atom labels and stereo bonds
  • No Color: don't color the stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for R at OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for R Chirality at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at Absolute Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at absolute stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at AND Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at AND stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Stereo Label for S at OR Centers
sci:arg.sci:help: Label to use for S Chirality at OR stereogenic centers

sci:arg.name: Zero Order Bonds
sci:arg.sci:help: Depiction options that control the drawing of zero-order bonds (hydrogen and dative bonds)

sci:arg.name: Hydrogen Bonds Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use to draw the lines that represent Hydrogen bonds

sci:arg.name: Dative Bonds Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the color to use to draw the lines that represent Dative bonds

sci:arg.name: Links and Actions
sci:arg.sci:help: Links and actions to be applied to the report element produced by this component.

sci:arg.name: Link
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional parameter specifying a link for the reporting element produced by this component. The Link value can be an internal report link or an external URL.

  • Internal: A string that points to a Link Target in the report. Both the Link and Link Target values need to match for an internal link to work.
  • External: A string that points to an external URL such as 'http://www.sitename.com', 'ftp://www.sitename.com', or a file URL. A file URL can be in one of these forms:
    • 'file:///C:/.../scitegic root/.../document.pdf' - when using an absolute path within the Pipeline Pilot installation folder
    • 'file://///machine_name/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a Windows UNC path visible to the Pipeline Pilot server
    • 'file:///relative_path/document.pdf' - when using a path, relative to @SciTegicRoot
    • 'file://machine_name.domain_name.com/C/.../document.pdf' - when using a path with a fully qualified machine name

sci:arg.name: Protocol Link
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies a link that runs a protocol. Editing this parameter opens up the Protocol Link Dialog.

sci:arg.name: Link Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how to display pages linked to the reporting element. Applies only if Link or Protocol Link are set for the component.

sci:arg.name: Link Target
sci:arg.sci:help: Sets this element as the destination for links from other elements in the report. The value of Link Target can be text or a property name, and should match the value of Link in another report component. In the resulting report, when the element with Link is clicked, the element with the matching Link Target is brought to the top of the report page.

sci:arg.name: Tooltip
sci:arg.sci:help: An optional tooltip for this reporting element.

sci:arg.name: HTML Attributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines attributes for the reporting element. These attributes can be used by JavaScript code that is embedded in or included by the HTML report. One very common attribute is "id" which allows access to the element using the document.getElementById(id) method. Event handlers such as "onclick" and "onmouseover" are also common attributes.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings
sci:arg.sci:help: Column settings control how the element appears when it is used inside a table.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings Header Text
sci:arg.sci:help: When the element is used within a Table component, this parameter sets the text displayed at the top of its column.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings Header Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Formatting to be applied to the reporting element produced by this component. Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, Color, and Background Color.

Notes:
  • Color: Sets font color
  • Background Image: Allows you to select a background image for the reporting element. This image must be accessible to the Pipeline Pilot server to be used (for example, you can copy images to the apps\scitegic\core\dataroot\data\Images folder in your Pipeline Pilot installation to make them available). Supported image types include .gif, .jpg, .png, and .bmp.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings Header Position
sci:arg.sci:help: When the element is used within a Table component, this parameter sets the position of the text displayed at the top of its column.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings Cell Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Formatting to be applied to the reporting element produced by this component. Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, Color, and Background Color.

Notes:
  • Color: Sets font color
  • Background Image: Allows you to select a background image for the reporting element. This image must be accessible to the Pipeline Pilot server to be used (for example, you can copy images to the apps\scitegic\core\dataroot\data\Images folder in your Pipeline Pilot installation to make them available). Supported image types include .gif, .jpg, .png, and .bmp.

sci:arg.name: Column Settings Cell Position
sci:arg.sci:help: When the element is used within a Table component, this parameter sets the position of the cells in the column.

sci:arg.name: Optimize Using Globals
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines if the image calculation data will be stored on each data record or in globals. Storing the image calculation data in globals generally improves the performance since less data is passed on data records. However, if data records that passed through the component are written into a cache that is reused outside of the current protocol you need to set this parameter to False.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates an image of a molecule for use in reports

The component generates a graphical representation of the input molecule as a report element. Supported image formats include PNG, JPEG, SVG, EMF, BMP and TIFF. SVG output may be the best choice if outputting to a PDF document. The image will be shown if the pipeline feeds into a writer or viewer from the reporting collection.

Including Live Molecular Data With Include Live Molecule set to True, this component is equivalent to the read-only version of the Chemistry Sketcher component. See parameter-level help for more details.

Notes:

  • For generated molecular images, use ImageSize and WidthToHeightRatio to modify the size and aspect ratio. The Position parameter should not be used to set the width and height dimensions. Using Position will stretch the image using a linear scaling in each direction that invariably looks poor.
  • The component does not check or calculate 2D coordinates for the input molecules. You can use 2D Coords to generate the coordinates. You could also use Ensure Molecule Coordinates to automatically check the coordinates and generate them if necessary.
  • Users with more than one of the Accelrys Draw or ISIS/Draw sketchers installed will see Accelrys Draw launched in preference to ISIS/Draw. Those sketchers should be run from the desktop at least once before the applet can properly launch them to display a molecule.
  • To create live, embedded chemistry in Office documents, use Office Chemistry Sketcher.

See Also:

  • Molecule to Image
A new image report element is added to the data record.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Property Location
sci:arg.sci:help: Describes whether to look for this property name on the current data record or the global data.

sci:arg.name: Property
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name of the property to display. This will typically be "PNG_Image" if the image was calculated using the Molecule to PNG component.

The value of Property Type determines if this is interpreted as a local property on a data record or a global property. (If global property, do not include the '@' prefix in the Property parameter.)

sci:arg.sci:help: CaptureStdoutStderr

sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Header Text
sci:arg.sci:help: The text displayed at the top of the column.

sci:arg.name: Header Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Formatting to be applied to this reporting element.

Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, and Color.

Notes:
Examples of available formatting options:
  • Font Size: Sets font size
  • Color: Sets font color

sci:arg.name: Header Position
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how the header is positioned. Editing this parameter opens up the Position Dialog, which enables you to change margins, paddings, width, and height.

sci:arg.name: Cell Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Includes options to control the formatting and position of the cells of the column.

sci:arg.name: Cell Format
sci:arg.sci:help:
Formatting to be applied to this reporting element.

Editing this parameter opens the Format Dialog. Options that can be changed by this parameter include Font, Font Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, and Color.

Notes:
Examples of available formatting options:
  • Font Size: Sets font size
  • Color: Sets font color

sci:arg.name: Cell Position
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies how the cells are positioned. Editing this parameter opens up the Position Dialog, which enables you to change margins, paddings, width, and height.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: CaptureStdoutStderr
sci:arg.sci:help: CaptureStdoutStderr

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates a column for a table in a report

Column components take Reporting objects as input (e.g., from a Text component) to create a table in a report. Typically, the data source for the table is branched and fed into Reporting components (such as a Text) which specify the data to go into each column of the table. The output of each Reporting component is fed into an individual Column component (i.e., one Column component per column of the table) which controls the formatting and position of each column in the table. The output of all of the Column components is sent into a single Table component.

Each column is added to the table in the order it is placed in the protocol. Each column in a table must have the same number of rows. Valid input for this component is a reporting data record (e.g., output from a Text component). The first data record that enters the Column component represents the first cell in the column, and each additional record makes up the subsequent cells in the column.

Header Text is the label displayed in the header at the top of the column.

Cell Options parameters control the formatting and position of the cells of the table, which hold the data.

Note:

  • As of Pipeline Pilot 6.0, tables can be generated from Reporting objects without Column components by placing the Reporting components that specify the table data in sequence (rather than branched).

See Also:

  • For more assistance in creating tables, see Table.
  • Report Design Essentials
A data record representing the column is sent to the pass port.
The input data records are all sent to the fail port.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Link Options Mapping
sci:arg.sci:help: Mapping of the Format parameter name to the Link Options parameter name.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The file or URL source to read

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.
  • Process Complex Data Header Lines: Data header lines are the lines in the SD format that precede the actual data. They can contain the data field name (enclosed in angular brackets <>), the data field number (as DTn), the external registry number (enclosed in parentheses), and other optional information. When this parameter is set to False, only the data field name is parsed and used to set the corresponding property name. All the other information in the line is ignored. When the parameter is set to true, all the information is parsed. The property name is set from either the field name in <> or the DTn. If both are present the field name takes priority and the DTn number is saved as an additional property named FieldName#DTn. The external registry number is saved as FieldName#ExtRegNum and any other information is saved as FieldName#OtherDataFieldInfo. When the molecules are written to an SD file, the data header lines are reconstructed from these properties. The default state of this parameter is False, as parsing, preserving, and eventually writing all the information in the data header lines can be costly, specially for SD files with many data fields.
  • Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types: 'H2' and 'H+' are two non-standard element types that can be assigned to atoms by the Accelrys Draw sketcher. They represent unattached Hydrogen (a Hydrogen molecule) and charged Hydrogen (a proton), respectively. When this parameter is selected, these atom types are converted to standard hydrogen atoms upon reading, with charges of 0 for H2 and +1 for H+. Otherwise, these atoms are read and perceived as unknown atom types, with 'H2' and 'H+' as the atom labels.
sci:arg.sci:legalval: Convert From H2 And H+ Atom Types

sci:arg.name: ReadProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: Select True to read the properties for each molecule (in addition to the structures)

sci:arg.name: ReadQueryInfo
sci:arg.sci:help: If properties starting with "QueryInfo" are present, use them to set up query information on the atoms and bonds. (This is how, for example, SMARTS query information can be preserved when writing to an SD format file.) This information only contains information that cannot be written out in MOL/SD format.

sci:arg.name: PutNameInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the name of each molecule

sci:arg.name: PutCommentInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the comment associated with each molecule

sci:arg.name: Global Templates
sci:arg.sci:help:
V3000 SD or MOL files containing template definitions for amino acid, nucleic acid or other residues or monomers. These templates can then be refered to by molecules read by the SD reader.

The default template file included in the Chemistry collection, data\Direct\Direct_templates.mol contains definitions for 22 amino acids and 8 DNA and RNA templates.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Loads 137,000 compounds from the Asinex vendor catalog

Reads molecules and property data from a zipped SD file containing approximately 137,000 compounds from Asinex.

See Also:

  • This is a specific instance of the SD Reader.
Data fields in the SD file will be added to the property fields

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Show Table Header
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies whether table headers should be visible or not.

sci:arg.name: Basic
sci:arg.sci:help: A basic table has no special formatting.

sci:arg.name: Appearance
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable '.ParameterName().', set Basic to "False"'); not Parameter('Basic');

sci:arg.name: Sortable
sci:arg.sci:help: A table may allow a user to sort contents by clicking on a table header.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable '.ParameterName().', set Show Table Header to true.'); Parameter('Show Table Header');

sci:arg.name: Colored
sci:arg.sci:help:
A table can be given a color to distinguish it from other tables.

These colors can be Inverted to become background colors.

sci:arg.name: Definition
sci:arg.sci:help: A table may be formatted to emphasize a first column that defines a rows content.

sci:arg.name: Single Line
sci:arg.sci:help:
A table can specify that its cell contents should remain on a single line, and not wrap. If cell contents are very long the column may become very wide and push all the columns to the right of it off screen. In that case, set Fixed.

Fixed single line tables will automatically ensure content that does not fit in a single line will receive "..." ellipsis.

sci:arg.name: Fixed
sci:arg.sci:help:
A special faster form of table rendering that does not resize table cells based on content.

Fixed single line tables will automatically ensure content that does not fit in a single line will receive "..." ellipsis.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('A table can be ' . ParameterName() . ' or Collapsing but not both at the same time.'); not (Parameter('Collapsing') and Parameter())

sci:arg.name: Selectable Rows
sci:arg.sci:help: A table can have its rows appear selectable.

sci:arg.name: Inverted
sci:arg.sci:help: A table's colors can be inverted.

sci:arg.name: Striped
sci:arg.sci:help: A table can stripe alternate rows of content with a darker color to increase contrast.

sci:arg.name: Celled
sci:arg.sci:help: A table may be divided each row into separate cells.

sci:arg.name: Column Count
sci:arg.sci:help: A table can specify its column count to divide its content evenly.

sci:arg.name: Collapsing
sci:arg.sci:help:
A table can be collapsing, taking up only as much space as its rows.

A table can either be Fixed or Collapsing but not both at the same time.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('A table can be Fixed or ' . ParameterName() . ' but not both at the same time.'); not (Parameter('Fixed') and Parameter())

sci:arg.name: Padded
sci:arg.sci:help: Rows in a table may sometimes need to be more compact or more padded for legibility.

sci:arg.name: Size
sci:arg.sci:help: A table can have small or large font.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: Constant GUID
sci:arg.sci:help:
Override an automatically set GUID inside the component with this value.

If set, HTML element(s) will have their IDs set using this value instead of a randomly generated one.

Spaces or special characters are not allowed, only alphanumeric. The ID is case-sensitive.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails(ParameterName() . ' must be alphanumeric. Spaces or special characters are not allowed.'); numValues(rMatch(Parameter(), '[^a-zA-Z0-9]+', 'ig')) == 0;

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Exclude Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-delimited list of properties which will not be rendered in an autogenerated table.

sci:arg.name: Horizontal Scrollbar
sci:arg.sci:help:
DataTables has the ability to show tables with horizontal scrolling, which is very useful for when you have a wide table, but want to constrain it to a limited horizontal display area.

When set for tables that do not go beyond screen width, columns will be sized to the width of their contents, making the table appear narrow.

sci:arg.name: Column Order
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Header Text names (which may differ from the corresponding property names), indicating the order the columns should appear. Any non-listed properties will be added as subsequent columns.

Note:

  • The column names are case-sensitive

sci:arg.name: Show Entries Choices
sci:arg.sci:help:
Choices on the "Show ... entries" pulldown menu above the table. The first choice is used to initially display the table. Use a comma to separate the choices.

Note: When used with a Data Connector component, all rows will be shown and this parameter setting will be ignored.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable '.ParameterName().', set Data Connector / Publisher Subscriber Model to "None"'); Parameter('Publisher Subscriber Model') eq 'None';

sci:arg.name: Array Value Display
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines how array values are separated when they are displayed in an autogenerated table.

sci:arg.name: Data Connector
sci:arg.sci:help: Parameters related to the Data Connector interactivity model.

sci:arg.name: Publisher Subscriber Model
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether the component is a publisher, subscriber or both. Setting to 'None' bypasses any Data Connector node.

sci:arg.name: Subscriber Event Handling
sci:arg.sci:help:
Setting the on subscription event handling method.

Notes:
The publisher component always highlights.

sci:arg.name: Publisher Event Handling
sci:arg.sci:help: Setting the publishing event type.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.sci:help:
Override an automatically set GUID inside the component with this value.

If set, HTML element(s) will have their IDs set using this value instead of a randomly generated one.

Spaces or special characters are not allowed, only alphanumeric. The ID is case-sensitive.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails(ParameterName() . ' must be alphanumeric. Spaces or special characters are not allowed.'); numValues(rMatch(Parameter(), '[^a-zA-Z0-9]+', 'ig')) == 0;

sci:arg.name: Advanced Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Advanced Options

sci:arg.name: Theme
sci:arg.sci:help:
Choose a visual theme for the content.

  • 2.2.1: released 06/2016
  • Default (v 2.1.8): released 02/2016
Semantic UI release history with detailed notes: https://github.com/Semantic-Org/Semantic-UI/releases

When the component collection is updated with a new Semantic UI release, the components in unmodified existing protocols will continue to point to a set release version. You can also point this parameter to a newer release if you wish by right-clicking the component and Replace with Latest Version then selecting a newer semantic theme release.

To add a new custom theme (e.g. developed in-house): do not change this component. Just add a new subfolder to the ScitegicRoot\apps\saber\semantic\dataroot\data\assets\semantic\ file folder. The subfolder should contain a compiled customized copy of the Semantic UI distribution. The name of the subfolder should be alphanumeric and it cannot contain spaces or special characters.

sci:arg.name: Include Format and Position CSS
sci:arg.sci:help: If set to True, all native Pipeline Pilot format and position settings will be included in the output document. Otherwise all native Pipeline Pilot formatting will be ignored.

sci:arg.name: Add Page Margins
sci:arg.sci:help: When not using native Scitegic CSS, add page margins. This will add small margins on each side of the page. Scitegic styles already include this.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: not Parameter('Include Format and Position CSS');

sci:arg.name: Animate Link Underlines
sci:arg.sci:help: When hovering over a link, the link's underline is revealed by animating it out from the center.

sci:arg.name: Web Browser
sci:arg.sci:help:
This parameter is only relevant when running the protocol in the Pipeline Pilot Professional Client. When running the protocol from a web hyperlink or a URL the value of this parameter is ignored.

The value specifies which web browser to open on your desktop to view the report.

sci:arg.name: Output Mode
sci:arg.sci:help:
Allows some alternative formatting and position settings to be used that may cause the HTML report output to behave and look more like the HTML generated with previous versions of Pipeline Pilot. This parameter is intended to be set on writers in protocols developed with previous versions of Pipeline Pilot where the output looks or behaves differently when run with the current version.

Always use the value of "Default" for new protocols or protocols under active development. The latest Reporting components may not behave correctly in HTML reports written with a non-default mode.

When set to "Pipeline Pilot 7.5", this parameter rolls back some of the improvements made in the name of standards compliance and formatting consistency, including:

  • The report will not include the HTML 4.01 Doctype declaration, which will cause Internet Explorer to render the report using quirks mode.
  • Position rules will not be strictly enforced, so Internet Explorer 6 will render borders and padding outside the specified width.
  • Horizontal alignment of block objects will not be supported, so you will not be able to, for example, center-align a table.
  • The page margins will not be set.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists the set of temporary files which will be converted by the network to true temporary file names

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help: Lists a set of properties (without the @) to be created on the property list for this protocol. Other properties are created on the global property list and so are accessible from all protocols.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When the network is run, whether we process once or until done for each process call

sci:arg.name: Accept Bootstrap
sci:arg.sci:help: Allow the use of Web Design (Bootstrap) collection components with the Semantic UI viewer? Generally speaking, this parameter should always be set to False to prevent the inadvertent mixing of the two frameworks.

sci:arg.name: Set IE Compatibility
sci:arg.sci:help:
When this flag is set to True (default), IE compatibility in the report is set to IE 10 (the minimum support level for Pipeline Pilot). For most users of IE, this should provide a stable environment to view Pipeline Pilot reports.

Switch off this setting, if necessary, to allow Internet Explorer to display content in the highest mode available. This is only required for users who view the report in Internet Explorer 11 or above and who need to enable facilities not available in IE 10 mode, such as WebGL and some HTML5/CSS features.

Note that even if you are viewing the report in another browser, other users may subsequently run the protocol or view the report in Internet Explorer, and so you may still need to set this IE Compatibility setting - but only in the rare case that your report requires something beyond the default IE 10 compatibility.
